questions.text: The glossopharyngeal nerve is transected accidentally during a surgical procedure in a 45-year-old male. Which of the following is most likely lost in his patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

options.label: B
options.text: General sensation from the tonsillar lining

options.label: C
options.text: Salivary secretion from the submandibular gland

questions.correct_answer: B. General sensation from the tonsillar lining

questions.text: During recovery from a gunshot wound of the right pelvis, the patient notices a lurch in his gait. When he lifts his left foot off of the ground, his pelvis dips down on the left side. The nerve that appears to have been injured is the

A 60-year-old man presents with history of headache, vertigo, ataxia and intermittent pain and weakness in his left arm initiate by using the left arm for daily activities. On examination, the left radial pulse is weak and the systolic BP on the left side is reduced by 30 mm HG. Doppler Ultrasound reveals reversal of flow in the left vertebral artery. What is likely underlying pathology which would explain the patient’s condition:

options.label: A
options.text: Critical stenosis of Right Vertebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Critical stenosis of Left Vertebral artery

options.label: C
options.text: Critical stenosis of First part of Subclavian artery

options.label: D
options.text: Critical stenosis of Third part of Subclavian artery

questions.correct_answer: C. Critical stenosis of First part of Subclavian artery

questions.text: A cyanotic infant was delivered in the emergency room. You found out that her great vessels were transposed. Which of the following would have led to patient’s cardiac anomaly?
questions.correct_answer: B. Non spiraling of Spiral septum

On initial physical examination, a 4,500-g neonate is noted to have an umbilical hernia, macroglossia, unusual ear creases, hemihypertrophy, and visceromegaly. Soon after delivery, he develops persistent hypoglycemia warranting treatment with intravenous dextrose. Of the following, this neonate is at INCREASED risk for

A 5-day-old female neonate is brought to the office in response to a call from the state laboratory reporting a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level higher than 200 mIU/L (normal <30 mIU/L) on her newborn screen. The neonate was born via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery at 40 weeks’ gestation with a birthweight of 3.5 kg. Her mother took levothyroxine for Hashimoto thyroiditis and prenatal vitamins during pregnancy. The neonate has been breastfeeding well on demand. Her vital signs are normal. She has mild jaundice and a small, reducible umbilical hernia. Her thyroid does not appear enlarged. The physical examination findings are otherwise normal. Confirmatory thyroid function tests show a TSH of 520 mIU/L (normal 0.6-5.6 mIU/L) and a free thyroxine of 0.5 ng/dL (6.4 pmol/L; normal 1.2-3.4 ng/dL [15.4-43.7 pmol/L]). Of the following, the MOST likely cause of this neonate’s laboratory findings is

A 7-year-old boy is seen for evaluation of swelling over his eyelids for 10 days. His mother reports that the swelling is more prominent upon waking and gradually improves throughout the day. The boy had an upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks ago. He has a history of mild intermittent asthma. He has a heart rate of 82 beats/min, respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min, and blood pressure of 105/62 mm Hg. He has periorbital edema and pitting edema of ankles. His chest is clear to auscultation. The rest of the physical examination findings are unremarkable. Laboratory data from spot urinalysis with microscopy are shown: Laboratory Test Result pH 6.5 Specific gravity 1.030 Leukocyte esterase Negative Nitrite Negative Blood 1+ Protein 3+ Red blood cells 5-10/HPF White blood cells < 5/HPF Of the following, the BEST next step in evaluation of this patient is

options.label: B
options.text: Renal function test, serum albumin, and complement levels

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat urinalysis 1 week after a trial of diphenhydramine

questions.correct_answer: B. Renal function test, serum albumin, and complement levels

questions.text: An 8-hour-old neonate who was delivered at 39 2/7 weeks’ gestational age is reported to be dusky in appearance and tachycardic. Neither the maternal history nor prenatal laboratory results are of concern. The neonate’s heart rate is 280 beats/min, respiratory rate is 80 breaths/min, and blood pressure is 40/20 mm Hg. The pulse oximeter will not give a reading on the right hand. Pulses are present throughout, but weak. Electrocardiography is performed. Of the following, the BEST next step in management is

A 3-year-old boy underwent a laparoscopic splenectomy 6 months ago to control hemolysis associated with hereditary spherocytosis. Of the following, this child's medical history MOST increases his risk for

A previously healthy 9-month-old female infant is seen in the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever and decreased appetite. She has no history of vomiting, diarrhea, cough, or nasal congestion. Her temperature is 39.5°C. She is alert and interactive. She is mildly dehydrated, and there is no focus of infection. A catheterized urine sample is collected. Urinalysis results are shown: Laboratory Test Result Leukocyte esterase 2+ Nitrite Negative White blood cells 20-50/HPF She fails an oral fluid challenge and is admitted to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics. Her urine culture grows 50,000 CFU/mL of Escherichia coli. Renal ultrasonography shows mild left hydronephrosis. Of the following, the MOST appropriate next step is to

A 2-year-old boy's parents are concerned about significant speech delay. He exhibits unusual dysmorphology, including malar and zygomatic hypoplasia with downslanting palpebral fissures; prominent nose; significant micrognathia and retrognathia; small, posteriorly rotated, and malformed ears; and lower eyelid colobomas with absent eyelashes. His father has similar dysmorphology. Of the following, the MOST likely reason for this boy's speech delay is

A 15-year-old girl is being evaluated as a new patient. She recently relocated to the United States from Mexico. Aside from a hole in her heart that was noted at birth, she reports being otherwise healthy. She has not had any operations, and is not taking any medications. She has no record of her prior immunizations. The girl describes recently feeling short of breath with nonstrenuous daily activities, needing to nap more frequently, and having fainted once while walking up the stairs at home. Although fatigued, she continues to perform well academically. On physical examination, her heart rate is regular at 100 beats/min, respiratory rate is 25 breaths/min, oxygen saturation is 80%, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Her height and weight are at the 50th percentile for age. She has a dusky appearance; a normal S1, loud S2, and no murmur; her liver is palpable 4 cm below the costal margin; and her fingernails are clubbed. She has stage 3 pubic hair and breast development. The remainder of her examination findings are unremarkable. Of the following, this adolescent’s MOST likely diagnosis is

A 4-year-old boy is seen for evaluation of diffuse abdominal pain and poor oral intake. The pain is mild, intermittent, and colicky, but is not associated with vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. His vital signs are stable. He developed a rash on his buttocks and legs 2 weeks ago. The rash is purpuric and has raised borders. He has nonpitting edema of the hands and ankles but no joint swelling. He has mild tenderness on palpation of the abdomen. The rest of his physical examination findings are unremarkable. Laboratory data are shown: Laboratory Test Result Blood White blood cell count 8,100/μL (8.1 × 109/L) Hemoglobin 12.1 g/dL (121 g/L) Platelet count 400 × 103/μL (400 × 109/L) Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 110 mm/h Blood urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL (5.0 mmol/L) Creatinine 0.5 mg/dL (44 μmol/L) Aspartate aminotransferase 36 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 38 U/L Serum albumin 3.8 g/dL (38 g/L) Urine Blood 3+ Red blood cells 20-50/HPF Protein 1+ A stool guaiac test has negative results. Of the following, the MOST appropriate initial treatment for this patient is

A 4-year-old boy is being evaluated for unusual movements and concerning neurologic findings. He displays dystonia, choreoathetosis, and spasticity. His parents report that he has had low tone and global developmental delay since 3 months of age. He was diagnosed with cerebral palsy at 2 years of age. He is nonverbal and exhibits increasingly frequent banging of his head and biting of his fingers, hands, and lips. He is nondysmorphic in appearance. A maternal male cousin has similar clinical findings. Genetic and biochemical screening is performed. Of the following, the test MOST likely to suggest this boy’s diagnosis is

A normally delivered one day old child was admitted with hoarseness of voice. Prenatal examinations and assays were performed in a timely manner and identified no abnormalities. A general physical examination of the baby was conducted, normal muscle tone was observed but the liver edge ~ 3 cm below the rib was palpated. No dysmorphic features were identified in the examination. A cardiac ultrasound was ordered to examine the heart, which indicated the presence of cardiac hypertrophy. Serum muscle enzymes, including aspartate aminotransferase, lactate dehydrogenase and creatine kinase were found to be elevated. Muscle biopsies show vacuolar myopathy with presence of glycogen. A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident in which he was the unrestrained driver. Paramedics report that his breath smelled of alcohol at the scene. Enroute to the hospital. the patient receives 2 L intravenous normal saline. In the emergency department: his blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. pulse is 130/min. He is admitted directly to the intensive care unit: where he is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. A decision is made to insert a central venous catheter. In addition to sterile draping during the procedure. which of the following actions would be most likely to prevent intravascular catheter—related infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Alcohol—based hand scrub prior to beginning the procedure

options.label: B
options.text: Daily application of topical mupirocin at the catheter site

options.label: C
options.text: Insertion of the catheter in the femoral vein

options.label: D
options.text: One dose of intravenous vancomycin prior to catheter insertion .

questions.correct_answer: A. Alcohol—based hand scrub prior to beginning the procedure

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the hospital with multiple injuries and bleeding from various sites. He is hypotensive. The patient receives an emergency blood transfusion as part of the resuscitation efforts. Abdominal ultrasound reveals splenic laceration and blood in the peritoneal cavity. Enroute to the operating room. the patient develops difficulty breathing, chills. and pain in the chest and back. Urine drainage from the Foley catheter was initially clear but now appears brown in color. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's new co findings?

A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department with fevers and malaise over the last 48 hours. He initially experienced fevers and chills which subsequently progressed to fatigue to the point that he had difficulty performing routine tasks this morning. He has also had a mild headache. The patient is retired and spends time gardening and swimming at a local public u pool. O/e the oropharynx is dry without lesions. Lung examination reveals coarse crackles bilaterally. The patient's abdomen is soft and mildly tender throughout with palpable splenomegaly. He has no rash or open wounds. A peripheral blood smear shown in the image. What is the most likely source of this infection?
Which one of the following is not the feature of PCOS?
Which one of the following is normal in pregnancy?
Which one of the following is not a part of HONAN criteria for the diagnosis of Bartholin Gland cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no recognizable Bartholin gland seen in the tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Tumour is correct in anatomical position

options.label: D
options.text: The tumour is located deep in labia majora

questions.correct_answer: A. There is no recognizable Bartholin gland seen in the tissue

questions.text: A 29 years old primigravida with 38 weeks of gestation has HBsAg test positive. Which of the following is correct about this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Anti HBe antibody will be the marker of infectivity and transmission

options.label: B
options.text: Breast feeding is contraindicated in hepatitis B

options.label: C
options.text: Hepatitis B virus can pass through breast milk

options.label: D
options.text: Mode of delivery is cesarean section to prevent vertical transmission

questions.correct_answer: C. Hepatitis B virus can pass through breast milk

questions.text: Primigravida with 37 weeks of gestation has oligohydramnios and pre-eclampsia. Her CTG in labour is suggestive of following pattern. What is the cause of this pattern?

A 32 years old G2P1L1 with 18 weeks of gestation and O negative blood group with partner’s blood group A positive has ICT positive with titers of 1:4. Her Quad test was positive for which she was advised to undergo amniocentesis and karyotype. How much Anti-D dose should be given to her before amniocentesis?

A 42 years old G3P2L2 patient has complete molar pregnancy and her USG is suggestive of bilateral theca lutein cysts of 6 cm each. She does not wish to conceive in future. Which of the following is correct mode of treatment in her?

options.label: A
options.text: Suction and evacuation with COC pills as contraceptives for 6 months

options.label: C
options.text: Hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with HCG monitoring

options.label: D
options.text: Suction evacuation with HCG monitoring followed by Hysterectomy after 6 months

questions.correct_answer: B. Hysterectomy followed by HCG monitoring

questions.text: A 21 years old nulliparous patient has unruptured ectopic for which she is undergoing multiple dose regimen of MTx therapy. The following table shows the details of her treatment. What is the next line of management from 17th July?

options.label: A
options.text: Give injection methotrexate, continue monitoring and complete 4 doses of methotrexate

options.label: B
options.text: Give injection methotrexate since b-HCG has not fallen by 15% from the first value

options.label: C
options.text: No need of further injections and no need of further monitoring

options.label: D
options.text: No need of further injections but do weekly b-HCG monitoring.

questions.correct_answer: D. No need of further injections but do weekly b-HCG monitoring.

questions.text: A 32 years old primigravida has 19 weeks of gestation with painless rupture of membranes with leakage of amniotic fluid. Her cervical os is not open and fetus is alive. What is your diagnosis?
Which one of the following is not a contraindication of external cephalic version?

A 32 years old primigravida has 36 weeks of gestation and her usg is suggestive of cephalic presentation with velamentous placenta along with membranes having vessels lying above internal os. Which of the following is correct about this case?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to painless profuse bleeding during labour causing maternal shock

options.label: B
options.text: Mode of delivery is cesarean section even when the baby is dead

options.label: C
options.text: APT test of the bleeding per vaginum shows no hemolysis of the blood

options.label: D
options.text: This is called as vasa previa type 2

questions.correct_answer: C. APT test of the bleeding per vaginum shows no hemolysis of the blood

questions.text: Identify the specimen?

A patient underwent radical hysterectomy for cervical carcinoma stage 1B1. It was found on histopathology that the lymph nodes were negative for cancer but the cervical cancer had spread to lower part of uterus. Which of the following is correct regarding this case?

options.label: A
options.text: The staging does not change and she requires no further treatment.

options.label: B
options.text: The staging changes to stage 2 and additional chemotherapy is needed

options.label: C
options.text: The staging changes to stage 2 and additional radiotherapy is needed

options.label: D
options.text: The staging does not change but she will require additional chemoradiation therapy.

questions.correct_answer: A. The staging does not change and she requires no further treatment.

questions.text: A 72 years old post-menopausal patient underwent exploratory laparotomy and it was found that she had fallopian tubal cancer which was spread till uterus. What is the stage of the disease?
Which one of the following cases is not having uterus?
Which one of the following structures is made from caudal end of Wollfian tubules in females?

A 37 years old nulliparous patient is having secondary amenorrhoea and infertility. Her hormonal profile is as follows: Sr. FSH is 0.2 IU/L Sr. Prolactin is 200 ng/ml Sr. Testosterone is 50ng/dl Sr. AMH is 2.2 ng/ml Which of the following is correct treatment for her infertility?

A 35 years old Primigravida with 36 weeks of gestation had road traffic accident followed by antepartum hemorrhage. Her uterus is stony hard. FHR of 90 beats per minute. Her vitals are stable. On PV examination cervix is 2 cm dilated, 30% effaced with cephalic presentation and station at -2. What is the plan of management in her?

options.label: B
options.text: Induction of labour by ARM followed by oxytocin drip

options.label: C
options.text: ARM followed by emergency cesarean section

options.label: D
options.text: Expectant management since she is hemodynamically stable

questions.correct_answer: C. ARM followed by emergency cesarean section

questions.text: Calculate the Bishop’s score of this case: cervix is 1 cm dilated, 40%effaced, mid-posed, firm and station is -1.

There is a 24 years old nulliparous patient who has purulent vaginal discharge and lower abdominal pain. Her UPT is negative and on examination, there is uterine tenderness. Which colour kit is suitable for her?
A 56 years old lady has endometrial hyperplasia which was causing post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following is not a risk factor for development of endometrial cancer?
A 23 years old primigravida with 10 weeks of gestation has uterine prolapse of stage 2. What is the best line of management in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Do MTP and then sling surgery

questions.text: A 52 years old patient has FIGO-1 fibroid of 4 cm which is causing post-menopausal bleeding. What is the best line of management in this case?

Sarcoma with lymphatic spread is?

questions.correct_answer: B. Benign squamous cells mixed with myoepithelial cells

questions.text: Not true about venous thrombus in comparison to arterial thrombus is?

questions.correct_answer: C. Endothelial injury is most common triggering event

questions.text: Cross matching is?

options.label: A
options.text: Donor serum + patient RBC + Combs serum

options.label: B

options.text: Donor RBC + patient serum+ combs Serum

A 24yrs, Primi-gravida presents to the casualty with generalised tonic-clonic convulsions. She is 28weeks pregnant. She was found to have elevated BP 160/100mm of Hg. Fundus examination revealed Papilledema. Neurological examination revealed Right sided hemiparesis. MRI was performed. What is best management in this patient?
Match the following Brainstem syndromes and their clinical features.

A 45-year-old man has recently moved from Delhi. He suffers a focal seizure followed by secondary generalization. He denies symptoms of active infection and has not suffered any recent trauma. His neurological examination has returned to normal in the emergency room. A magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Lancosamide with biopsy of the lesion.

questions.text: Match the following:

A 33-year-old woman is seen in your office for evaluation of fatigue, malaise, and mild right upper quadrant discomfort, ongoing for the past 1 month. Her medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, and her only medication is levothyroxine. Her examination result is notable only for mildly tender hepatomegaly. On further questioning, she reports no risk factors for viral hepatitis. She does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs. Her mother has lupus, and a maternal aunt has rheumatoid arthritis. Laboratory test results are notable for ALT 480 U/L, AST 211 U/L, total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 89 U/L, total protein 9.1 g/dL, albumin 4.1 g/dL, and TSH 2.1 µIU/mL. Her anti smooth muscle antibody titre is elevated. Which of the following statements about her likely diagnosis is true?

options.label: A
options.text: This condition most often occurs in men.

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment of choice is prednisone with azathioprine.

options.label: C
options.text: There is a very low risk of developing cirrhosis.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not recur after liver transplant

questions.correct_answer: B. Treatment of choice is prednisone with azathioprine.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with chronic hepatitis C–associated cirrhosis presents to the emergency room with confusion and abdominal pain. He is noted to have ascites and asterixis. Which statement is true regarding care of this patients?

options.label: A
options.text: Patients with ascites fluid total protein <1.1 g/dL and serum bilirubin >2.5 mg/dL should receive prophylactic antibiotics as risk of SBP is high.

options.label: B
options.text: Endoscopic variceal sclerotherapy is the preferred option for secondary prophylaxis of variceal haemorrhage.

options.label: C
options.text: If Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score more than 10 consider liver transplant.

questions.correct_answer: A. Patients with ascites fluid total protein <1.1 g/dL and serum bilirubin >2.5 mg/dL should receive prophylactic antibiotics as risk of SBP is high.

questions.text: 30-year-old male is incidentally detected to have high BP. His Urine Chloride levels are high. Blood gas analysis revealed Metabolic alkalosis with an unmeasurable Renin levels. Which is the likely cause:
Which of the following is the best strategy to treat a patient with CKD who has a hemoglobin level of 5.8 g/dL, iron saturation of 12%, and ferritin level of 300 mg/dL?

options.label: C
options.text: Intravenous iron (to achieve saturation > 20%), then epoetin ? if hemoglobin is < 10 g/dL

options.label: D
options.text: Intravenous iron (to achieve saturation > 20%), then epoetin ? if hemoglobin is < 12 g/dL

questions.correct_answer: C. Intravenous iron (to achieve saturation > 20%), then epoetin ? if hemoglobin is < 10 g/dL

questions.text: In diabetes all of the following statement are correct EXCEPT

options.label: A
options.text: Recognised endocrine causes of diabetes include Acromegaly and Cushing’s syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: The majority of type 2 diabetes mellitus patients die from cardiovascular disease

options.label: C
options.text: Fasting blood sugar more than 126 establishes diagnosis of diabetes

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with type 2 diabetes are more prone to ketoacidosis as compared to type 1

questions.correct_answer: D. Patients with type 2 diabetes are more prone to ketoacidosis as compared to type 1

questions.text: Following statements about Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis is true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: It is a defect in H+-K+ ATPase pump

options.label: B
options.text: It is associated with Urine pH < 5.5 with Metabolic acidosis

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with hypocitraturia and increased risk of nephrocalcinosis

options.label: D
options.text: It causes paracellular defect in Calcium and Magnesium reabsorption

questions.correct_answer: B. It is associated with Urine pH < 5.5 with Metabolic acidosis

questions.text: Respiratory system disorders commonly present with cough. Following statements are true regarding the symptom EXCEPT

options.label: A
options.text: Sputum production more than 100ml/day is bronchorrhea

options.label: B
options.text: Significant expectoration involves mucopurulent sputum production

options.label: C
options.text: Significant expectoration is common in Interstitial lung disease

options.label: D
options.text: Non-significant expectoration is common in cases of Upper respiratory tract infection

questions.correct_answer: C. Significant expectoration is common in Interstitial lung disease

questions.text: A 70 years old obese gentleman presents to the emergency department with acute onset of breathlessness. He is a known case of type 2 DM for 10-12 years with poor compliance for antidiabetic drugs. He smokes 20 cigarettes/day for the past 40 years. He was diagnosed as COLD and started on bronchodilator inhalation 10 years back, but he has no further follow-up. He gives history of progressive worsening of breathlessness which is associated with exertion for past 6 months. What is best test in the emergency room to diagnose heart failure?

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.text: Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of Axial dominant arthropathy. Which of the following components of patient history is more commonly associated with ankylosing spondylitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute, spontaneous onset of low back pain

options.label: B
options.text: Onset of symptoms after age 50 years

options.label: D
options.text: Symptoms are typically worse in the morning

questions.correct_answer: D. Symptoms are typically worse in the morning

questions.text: A 26 year old male has been complaining of back pain for last one year. His pain radiates from the back to right buttock and thigh down to legs. On examination he has mild sensory loss over dorsum of foot and weakness of extension of great toe on the right side. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.correct_answer: A. PIVD L4-L5 Postero lateral / Paracentral

questions.text: A 42 year old female presents with tingling and numbness in right hand that awakens her in the middle of the night for last two weeks. She also gives history of being treated for diabetes and hypothyroidism for last 3 years by an endocrinologist. Which of the following ain’t true about this condition from the following options ?

options.label: A
options.text: Splintage is helpful only in few initial months of onset of symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Motor Symptoms appear early in the course of the disease

options.label: C
options.text: Durakn’s Test is the most specific clinical test in the diagnosis

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most common focal compression neuropathy

questions.correct_answer: B. Motor Symptoms appear early in the course of the disease

questions.text: A 9 year old child is brought by his parents with chief complains of pain and swelling in right thigh which have exaggerated since last couple of weeks. His Thorough examination was done earlier which revealed Increased TLC , Neutrophils and ESR. His repeated blood cultures went Negative. X Ray Was done which showed lesion in femur mainly in diaphysis with some laminated periosteal reaction. What is the NEXT investigation that should be done ?
About fracture healing, all are true, except :

options.label: A
options.text: Lower limb long bones heal faster than other bones

options.label: B
options.text: Fracture in children heal faster than in adults

options.label: C
options.text: Oblique and spiral fractures heal faster than transverse fractures

questions.correct_answer: A. Lower limb long bones heal faster than other bones
